conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with a semi-cylindrical object and light entering along axis OA.
Point C is at a distance of \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}R\) from O on the straight line part of the semi-cylinder.
Light entering perpendicularly to the flat surface at OA has no refraction.
At point C, refraction occurs as the light is no longer entering perpendicularly.
No light emitted from the right side suggests total internal reflection at the curved surface.
Need to find the angle of incidence at point C and trace the light path.
Using trigonometry to find the angle of incidence \(\theta_i\) with a right triangle.
Point C is on the flat surface, distance from O to C is \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}R\).
The angle of incidence \(\theta_i\) is between the incident ray and the normal at point C.
Realizing the angle should be zero if both are along OA, indicating a misunderstanding.
Re-evaluating the problem statement about light entering at point C.
Light entering at point C would be at an angle relative to the normal.
Visualizing the flat surface as vertical and OA as horizontal with point C to the right of O.
